IUCNDefintion: Forest consists of a continuous stand of trees and includes both forested areas (generally with a closed canopy) and wooded areas (canopy more open, but see 2. Savanna).
IUCNNotes: Includes primary and secondary forest habitats and forest edges/margins.
Notes: Forest considered all copernicus discrete land covers classes  between 111-126. All closed forest types (111-116) are considered to be forest per se. A fractional tree cover cutoff was then used to assign the rest (Also from copernicus,> 50% tree covered).

IUCNDefintion: Distributed across the high latitudes of the northern hemisphere (occurring between 50 and 60° N) in a broad belt across Eurasia and North America. Trees are predominantly coniferous (pine, fir and spruce), though a few deciduous genera are nearly ubiquitous in their distribution and are locally common (see 1.4). Includes forest types described as taiga, coniferous, coniferous deciduous, and broadleaved deciduous.
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and within the boreal climatic zones. As the latter occur also on temperate high altitude areas, another constrain might be necessary

IUCNDefintion: Included for completeness sake - probably little forest occurs at these high latitudes.
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and not in Class 2. Note that in climatology,  boreal forests are within the subartic

IUCNDefintion: Stunted forest on subantarctic islands. Forest on Auckland and Snares Islands (to New Zealand), bosques sub-antárticos (Argentina).
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class, below 0 latitude, not in the subtropics and in climate zones characterised by oceanic climate

IUCNDefintion: Distributed in the temperate regions (under the influence of moist continental climates) of North and South America (primarily Chile), Europe, Asia (China/Korea/Japan) and Australia/New Zealand. Includes forest types described as coniferous, broadleaved evergreen, broadleaved deciduous, and mixed; also riverine and alluvial. The deciduous trees shed their leaves in the winter season. In the northern hemisphere, the coniferous (or needleleaf evergreen) component increases towards the north where the mixed forest transitions to Boreal Forest (see 1.1). Includes Mediterranean forests but these might also be placed under 1.5 [needs resolution ] and pine-oak forests found in Mexico and the southern US.
DataCondition: ((forest == 100 && subtropics == 1) && ((koeppen >= 8 && koeppen <= 10) || ( koeppen >= 12 && koeppen <= 16) || (koeppen >= 17 && koeppen <= 18) || (koeppen >= 21 && koeppen <= 26) || ( biome >= 4 && biome <= 5) || (biome == 8 && koeppen == 7)  ) )
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and in a temperate climate zone and not being in the subtropics (condition == 1 ). Adjustments made for climate pockets and extensions of temperate biomes

IUCNDefintion: Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia. Typically forests that experience a dry season of several months. Includes forest types described as deciduous, makatea, atoll/beach, palm, thorn and spiny; Florida rockland hammocks, pune rocklands, marine hammocks, shellmounds (last 4 from SE USA); bosque chaco, espinal, bosque de algarrobo/prosopis (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay); forest in the seasonally dry inter- Andean valleys.
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class, in the subtropics and in savannah or steppe-like climate zones or biomes. Also see savannah

IUCNDefintion:
Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally below c.1,200 m (but varying with geography and topography).
Includes (lowland/hill rain/wet/humid/moist) forest types described as evergreen or semi-evergreen or broadleaved evergreen, deciduous, dipterocarp and mixed; also riparian/riverine and gallery, Sierra maestra se Cuba, selva paranaense, bosque de quebrada, bosque sammofilo (Uruguay)
IUCNNotes: Bamboo forests found at these elevations and conditions are included here
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and in the most tropical zones and subtropical humid climate. Furthermore koeppen zone 14 & 15 in the subtropics (China, Paraguay)

IUCNLevel: 1.7. Forest – Subtropical/tropical mangrove vegetation above high tide level
IUCNDefintion: Distributed in the subtropics and tropics, growing in sheltered estuaries and along coastlines in brackish or salt water
IUCNNotes: Species are above the high tide level - see 12.7.
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and classified as mangrove according to the CIFOR 2016 layer

IUCNDefintion: Distributed in the subtropics and tropics. Typically flooded for at least part of the year and dependent on this flooding for its existence. Includes forest types described as peat swamp, bog, and varzea/igapo.
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class and being peat forming vegetation (swamp, bog, marches, … ) in tropics and suptropics according to the CIFOR dataset

IUCNDefintion: Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally above c.1,200 m (but varying with geography and topography).Includes (lower and upper montane/mountain rain/wet/moist) forest types described as cloud, mossy, elfin, dwarf, Polylepis, coniferous, pine, pine-oak and evergreen, mesophyllous, yungas (to Peru/Bolivia/Argentina).
IUCNNotes: Includes (lower and upper montane/mountain rain/wet/moist) forest types described as cloud, mossy, elfin, dwarf, Polylepis, coniferous, pine, pine-oak and evergreen, mesophyllous, yungas (to Peru/Bolivia/Argentina).
DataCondition: ((forest == 100 && mountains == 1 && subtropics == 2) && ((koeppen >=1 && koeppen < 3) || ((koeppen == 12 || koeppen == 15) && elevation >= 1200 ) || ((koeppen >= 8 && koeppen <= 9) && biome == 3)) || ((biome == 10 || biome ==1) && (koeppen >= 9 && koeppen <= 10)  ) || ( (biome == 1 && koeppen >=22) || (biome == 10 && koeppen >=29)) )
Notes: Condition being of Level 1 forest class, in the tropical zones or within tropical or suptropical lattitude. Furthermore being montaneous according to the global mountain mask. Adjustment made for pockets in subtropical climate and biomes

IUCNDefintion: Savannas are transitional between grasslands and forests. They are ecosystems dominated by a grass ground cover with an overstorey of widely spaced trees and shrubs. May be referred to as savanna woodlands, savanna parklands, savanna grasslands, low tree/shrub savannas, thicket/scrub savannas. Distributed largely in Africa, Australia (mostly northern), Asia (India, SE Asia) and South America.
Notes: Savanna being shrubs or herbaceous vegetation (class 20/30) or open forest with less than 50% forest cover (121 - 126). They furthermore exclusively occur in the tropical/suptropical savanna climate (koeppen == 3) and dry or alternatively in steppe-like climates in sub-tropics ( koeppen == 6 || koeppen == 11 || koeppen == 14) ) below 30 latitude. In contrast to forest it is assumed that savannah have less than 50% closed tree cover

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined. Includes savanna types described as Eucalyptus and Acacia woodland, mopane/miombo/Brachystegia woodlands (Africa), cerrado/campos/caatinga (Brazil, Guiana), chaco seco (Argentina/Uruguay) and mulga (Australia), oak woodlands (mid- western USA)
Notes: Hard being not defined. Set to the Koeppen savanna climate zone

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined. Includes savanna types described as pantanal (Brazil/Bolivia/Paraguay), chaco or chaco húmedo (Paraguay/Bolivia/Argentina), and llanos (Venezuela/Colombia).
Notes: Hard being not defined. Set to the other climatic zones defined as being savanna
Copernicus land cover shrub (20). Furthermore not being Savannah and usually having less than 50% closed tree cover fraction

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined
Notes: As for subarctic forests, but defined for land cover type shrubland. Occuring in polar climate

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined
Notes: As for subantarctic forests, but defined for land cover type shrubland

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined
Notes: As for boreal forests, but defined for land cover type shrubland

IUCNDefintion:
Needs to be defined. Compare to 3.5, 4.4 and 4.5
Includes semi-deserts dominated by shrubs, coastal beach shrublands (e.g. to be added)
DataCondition: ((shrub == 300 && subtropics == 1) && ((koeppen >=8 && koeppen <= 10) || (koeppen >= 12 && koeppen <= 19) || (koeppen >= 21 && koeppen <= 26) || (((biome >= 4 && biome <= 5) || biome == 8 || biome == 10 ) && koeppen >= 27) ))
Notes: As for temperate forests, but excluding those climate zones that are considered warm / mediterranean. Exclusion also on being not in the belt of cancer / tropics with adjustment for climatic pockets and biomes

IUCNDefintion: Needs to be defined. Found mainly on the lowlands. Compare to 3.4, 4.4 and 4.5. Includes (arid/semi-desert/dry) shrubland types described as succulent, thorn or thorn scrub, karoo, strandveld (South Africa), Kalahari (Botswana, Namibia, South Africa), restingas (coastal scrub in Brazil); coastal strand; xerophyllous scrub; chapparal (Mexico and SW US); enclave, matorral sammofilo, matorral seco (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).
Notes: Shrubland in arid or savanna climate

IUCNDefintion: Humid/semi-humid shrubland types described as evergreen and found mainly on the lowlands. Includes vegetation on river islands and in the riparian zones; matorral húmedo (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay)
Notes: Shrubland and in sub/tropical most climate zones

IUCNDefintion: Alpine/subalpine shrubland types around and above the tree-line in mountainous regions. Some of the shrublands are dominated by rhododendron, juniper or birch; prepuna (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).
DataCondition: ( (shrub == 300 && subtropics == 2 && (mountains == 1 || alpine_abovetreelines == 1)) && ((koeppen >=1 && koeppen < 3) || ((koeppen >= 9 && koeppen <= 12 || (koeppen == 15 || koeppen >= 29 ) || (biome == 10) || (biome == 1 && koeppen >=22) ) && elevation >= 1200 )) )
Notes: As for tropical/subtropical forests, but defined for land cover type shrubland. Some small changes to account differences above the tree line in subtropical regions

IUCNDefintion: Distributed in Mediterranean ecosystems of Australia, Chile, Europe/North Africa, North America (primarily California) and South Africa. Evergreen shrubs and sclerophyllous trees (low in stature with a relatively open canopy) are the dominant plant forms, and frequent fires have historically played an important role in regulating community composition and structure. The areas are characterized by warm dry summers. Includes shrubland types described as garrigue, chaparral (California), maquis (Mediterranean), mallee or mallee scrub (Australia), matorral (Chile) and fynbos (South Africa).
Notes: In mediterranean climate zones, so mainly temperate meditteranean zones with warm to hot summers ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mediterranean_climate ) and has to be above / below the belt of cancer (|23.5| latitude)

IUCNDefintion: Grasslands occur in regions with warm growing seasons and moderate water shortages. Native grasslands are comprised of grasses and broadleaved herbaceous plants, and are either without woody plants, or the latter are very sparsely distributed (see also 2. Savanna).
Notes: Grassland according to Copernicus (class 30 - herbaceous vegetation). Condition of natural grassland being not a pasture and have little to no tree cover. Also bare/sparse vegetation or moss/lichen that is not already a desert

IUCNDefintion: Grasslands which have developed over permafrost. Confined to the northern hemisphere where it encircles the north pole and extends south to the Boreal Forests. The area is characterized by its extremely cold desert-like conditions.
DataCondition: (grass == 400 && ( (koeppen >= 19 && koeppen <= 20) || (koeppen >= 23 && koeppen <= 24) || ((koeppen >= 27 && koeppen <= 30) && (biome == 6 || biome == 11 || (biome == 13 && subtropics == 1)) || (biome == 6 && koeppen == 7) ) ) )
Notes: Defined as for in boreal areas, but for grasslands. Now with biome addition for correcting iceland as well other climatic pockets

IUCNDefintion: Not defined
Notes: Not defined. Set to grass or moss & lichen occurring in polar climate

IUCNDefintion: Tussock grassland on subantarctic islands.
Notes: As for forst, but here for grassland. Subantarctic island climate

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. See 3.4, 3.5 and 4.5. Includes grassland types described as prairies (North America); steppe (Eurasia); calcareous; siliceous; edaphic; pampa or pampas (South America); pastizal patagónico, patagonia, pastizal pampeano (Argentina).
DataCondition: ((grass == 400 && subtropics == 1) && ((koeppen >=7 && koeppen <= 10) || (koeppen >= 12 && koeppen <= 16) || (koeppen >= 17 && koeppen <= 18) || (koeppen >= 21 && koeppen <= 26) || ((koeppen >= 27 && (biome >= 4 && biome <= 5) || biome == 8 || biome == 10)) ) )
Notes: Grassland in temperate climate as well as arid steppes for North america. Not beeing in the tropics (above/below belt of cancer), while adjusting for other climatically suitable pockets and biomes

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. See 3.4, 3.5 and 4.4. Includes (arid/dry) grassland types described as hummock/tussock (Australia); estepa (Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay).
Notes: Grassland in dry savanna and suptropical arid dry climates

IUCNDefintion: Not defined.
Notes: Grassland that is in tropical climate and not already one of the other climates

IUCNDefintion: Sometimes also referred to as alpine tundra. The night time temperatures are usually below freezing, but the soils are well- drained.
DataCondition: ((grass == 400 && (alpine_abovetreelines == 1 || mountains == 1)) && ((koeppen >= 1 && koeppen < 3) || ((koeppen == 11 || koeppen == 12 || koeppen == 15 || (koeppen >= 29 && subtropics == 2) || biome == 10 ) && elevation >= 1200 )) )
Notes: Montaneous grassland in tropics and subtropics

IUCNDefintion: Not defined
IUCNNotes: Inland wetlands correspond to the wetland types recognized by Ramsar. Note that other aquatic habitats are dealt with under other habitats (see 1. Forest, 4. Grassland, 9-12. Marine, 13. Coastal and 15. Artificial).
Notes: Wetlands being herbaceously water cover (90) or permanent water covered (80) according to Copernicus

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. Includes waterfalls
Notes: Permanent waterarea and of class 3 in the GLWD and permanent waterstructure in last 20 years

IUCNDefintion: Not defined
Notes: Seasonally flooded land and wetland complexes. River in GLWD and non-permanent water

IUCNDefintion: Shrub swamps, shrub-dominated freshwater marshes, shrub carr, alder thicket on inorganic soils.
Notes: Swamp forest or wetland complexes dominated by predominatly water

IUCNLevel: 5.4. Wetlands (inland) – Bogs, marshes, swamps, fens, peatlands
IUCNDefintion: Generally over 8 ha. Also includes mires. Bogs are peat-accumulating systems fed only by rainwater and thus have very low nutrient levels. They are usually strongly acidic, and water flow is restricted. The water table is either at or just below the surface and remains relatively constant. Fens have a predominantly peat substrate, but the peat is shallower and more decomposed than bogs. They are fed by both rain and groundwater resulting in low to moderate nutrient and acidity levels. The water table is typically just below the peat surface but there are small noticeable fluctuations. Swamps are relatively high in nutrients supplied via surface runoff and groundwater from the surrounding land. The water table is usually above some of the ground surface, but there are large, seasonal fluctuations. Marshes are characterized by large periodic fluctuations of water table or water level.
IUCNNotes: Excludes saline marshes (see 5.16 and 5.17). Note that the size difference between marshes coded here versus under 5.7 or 5.8.
Notes: Wetland and of class 8 in the GLWD. Alternatively flooded grassland in marshy forests

IUCNDefintion: Over 8 ha. Includes large oxbow lakes (see 13.5).
Notes: Permanent water and of lake class according to GLWD or Hydrolakes

IUCNDefintion: Over 8 ha. Includes floodplain lakes (see 13.5).
Notes: Wetland and of class 9 in GLWD or lake in Hydrolakes. Furthermore being known to seasonally vary

IUCNDefintion: Ponds (below 8 ha), marshes and swamps on inorganic soils; with emergent vegetation water-logged for at least most of the growing season.
Notes: Wetland and of class 4 in the GLWD. Assumed to be small in area

IUCNDefintion: Below 8 ha. On inorganic soils; includes sloughs, potholes, seasonally flooded meadows, sedge marshes.
Notes: Wetland and of class 12 in the GLWD. Assumed to be small in area

IUCNDefintion: Not defined
Notes: NOT YET MAPPED.

IUCNLevel: 5.10. Wetlands (inland) – Tundra wetlands (inc. pools and temporary waters from snowmelt)
IUCNDefintion: Includes tundra pools and temporary waters from snowmelt.
Notes: Wetlands being in tunra and subartic regions

IUCNLevel: 5.11. Wetlands (inland) – Alpine wetlands (inc. temporary waters from snowmelt)
IUCNDefintion: Includes alpine meadows, seepages, temporary waters from snowmelt.
Notes: Alpine wetlands being in mountains of zone 1-4 (over 1000m, not a basin)

IUCNDefintion: Wetlands influenced by heated geothermal water or chemistry derived from current or former geothermal activity. Often found in volcanically active areas.
Notes: NOT YET MAPPED.

IUCNDefintion: Created by a river dividing into multiple branches, these usually rejoin and continue to the sea. They often occur on former lake beds. In some cases a river flowing into a flat arid area splits into channels which then evaporate as it progresses into the desert.
IUCNNotes: The Inner Niger Delta and Peace–Athabasca Delta are notable examples. The Amazon has an inland delta before the island of Marajó and the Okavango Delta is the best example of a desert inland delta .
Notes: Mapped as inland wetland complex (respective classes from GLWD) afar from the intertidal zone.

IUCNLevel: 5.14. Wetlands (inland) – Permanent saline, brackish or alkaline lakes
IUCNDefintion: Not defined
Notes: Wetland and of class 7 in the GLWD

IUCNLevel: 5.15. Wetlands (inland) – Seasonal/intermittent saline, brackish or alkaline lakes and flats
IUCNDefintion: Not defined
Notes: Mapped as wetland complex under the assumption that intertidal brackish water supplies the source

IUCNDefintion: Desert consists of arid landscapes with a sparse plant cover, except in depressions where water accumulates. The sandy, stony or rocky substrate contributes more to the appearance of the landscape than does the vegetation.
Notes: Anything that is not already a rocky area (category 6) and in hot and cold desert areas of the world

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. [Deserts where the main form of precipitation is rain, thus would include the Arabian Desert; various Australian deserts - Great Sandy, Victoria, Simpson, Gibson and Sturt; Sahara; and the Thar in India].
Notes: Bare Area in hot desert climate zone

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. [Not clear, but might include the Takla Makan Desert in China, and the desert areas of Turkestan and possibly the Iranian Desert].

IUCNDefintion: Not defined. [Deserts where the main form of precipitation is snow or fog, and thus would include the Atacama Desert (Peru and Chile), Gobi Desert (China and Mongolia), Namib Desert (Namibia and bit of South Africa), Antarctica and parts of the Arctic].
Notes: Deserts in cold steppes or polar climate

IUCNDefintion: Includes cereal fields, rice paddies, perennial crops, orchards and groves (but see 14.3 and 14.4).
IUCNNotes: Secondary grasslands may be coded here or under 14.2, depends on the usage.
Notes: All copernicus land categories with arable land are considered arable land. Small fields can be considered rural gardens (see 14.4) and are excluded previously.

IUCNDefintion: Includes fertilized or re-seeded permanent grasslands, sometimes treated with selective herbicides, with very impoverished flora and fauna. Also includes secondary grasslands and wooded farmland.
Notes: Broad grassland, shrubland and herbaceous vegetation cover that is also predominantly used as pasture site. Custom Global pasture mask

IUCNDefintion: A plantation is an intentional planting of a crop, on a larger scale, usually for uses other than cereal production or pasture. The term is currently most often used for plantings of trees and shrubs. The term tends also to be used for plantings maintained on economic bases other than that of subsistence farming. Plantations are typically (but not exclusively) found in tropical or semitropical countries and usually require resident labourers.
Notes: TBD!  Plantations being defined as all tree covered land that is 'forest' according to the Copernicus land cover map as well as 'planted forest' according to the IIASA developed Forest management layer

IUCNDefintion: Rural gardens are located in a rural setting, serving families whose main income comes from wage labour (rural or urban). Rural gardens differ from arable land production by the following features which are usually, but by no means in all cases, found simultaneously: (1) cropping plants for personal consumption that cannot be collected nor supplied by arable farming, (2) small plots, (3) proximity to the house, (4) fencing, (5) mixed or dense planting of a great number of annual, semi-permanent, and perennial crops, (6) a high intensity of land use, (7) land cultivation several times a year, (8) permanence of cultivation, and (9) cultivation with hand implements. These gardens also provide space and/or fodder for the raising of small animals (usually poultry, rodents and small ruminants). In extreme cases, the rural garden may be the only source of livelihood and income for the rural poor. If enough space is available, small cash crops may be produced and exchanged or sold for purchased food.
IUCNNotes: Market gardens should be coded here.
Notes: Very challenging to map, given that this habitat is a mixture of biophysical and socioeconomic parameters (there is no way to quantify wage labour spatially). Here defined as croplands sites in the sub-urban boundary area (500m near urban land cover) where the IIASA field size indicates a field of small size. Furthermore limited to the tropics and sub-tropics (23.5° above and below the equator)

IUCNDefintion: Occurs throughout the world. Usually metropolitan and commercial areas dominated by asphalt, concrete and roof. Includes buildings, lawns and parks
Notes: Urban areas are urban covered land according to Copernicus or bare land that is not already a desert or trees/parks in urban areas according to the IIASA developed Forest management layer.

IUCNDefintion: Former subtropical or tropical forest that has been extensively cleared or impacted by human activities. Often there is some degree of regeneration or there are small fragments of forest remaining.
IUCNNotes: There is currently no differentiation between lowland and montane types.
Notes: Not mapped. Potentially added in the future.  Implies that conversion to plantation or reforestation is excluded, but natural regeneration can happen. It basically represents largely clear-felled forest with some degree of regeneration.
